title: The Chinese Embassy in Suriname donated US$10,000 worth of relief supplies to NCCR Suriname
description: On June 22, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Suriname donated US$10,000 worth of relief supplies to the National Coordination Center for Disaster Relief (Nationaal Coördinatie Centrum Suriname; NCCR). The donation consisted of more than 200 packages of materials such as food and daily necessities.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
The Chinese Embassy in Suriname donated US$10,000 worth of relief supplies to NCCR Suriname

# Description
On June 22, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Suriname donated US$10,000 worth of relief supplies to the National Coordination Center for Disaster Relief (Nationaal Coördinatie Centrum Suriname; NCCR). The donation consisted of more than 200 packages of materials such as food and daily necessities.
justification: Humanitarian aid project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Relief supplies consisting of food and daily necessities for disaster relief

title: ICBC provides $30 million loan for Phase 2 of Low-Income Housing Project (Linked to Project ID#36772)
description: On March 27, 2018, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and the Surinamese Postal Savings Bank (Surinaamse Postspaarbank or SPSB) — a state-owned bank in Suriname — signed a $30 million loan agreement for Phase 2 of the Low-Income Housing Project. The loan carries a 3-year (36-month) maturity. The other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance a $70 million commercial contract between SPSB, Dalian International & Technical Cooperation Group Co Ltd. (CDIG) and the Housing Construction Fund for Lower Income Groups (Fonds Woningbouw Lager Inkomensgroepen). The Government of Suriname issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the ICBC loan to SPSB on March 27, 2018.   The purpose of this project is to construct 700 low-income housing units in the locality of Morgenstond (Dutch: Morgenstaat).   CDIG is the contractor responsible for implementation. The project officially commenced on or around March 16, 2018. It has reportedly employed 100 Chinese workers and 300 Surinamese workers. However, as of March 2022, AidData had not identified any evidence of project completion.   There are some indications that the ICBC loan issued for Phase 2 of Low-Income Housing Project may have underperformed vis-a-vis lender expectations. The Government of Suriname defaulted on its sovereign debt obligations three times during the COVID-19 pandemic. In December 2021, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) announced that ‘Suriname owes arrears to China and India, which have provided assurances, although less specific than those provided by the Paris Club creditors, that they intend to work with Suriname towards a debt restructuring that will restore sustainability. China has consented to [IMF] financing notwithstanding these arrears. [...] An update will be circulated to the [IMF] Executive Board not later than one week prior to the scheduled Board consideration. On the basis of the Surinamese authorities’ commitment noted above, staff expect that debt to China and India will be treated on comparable terms with other bilateral creditors. The arrears constitute a form of financing contribution to the program. China and India have acknowledged that Suriname will continue to run arrears on their official debt until a debt treatment can be agreed.’ The IMF also disclosed in December 2021 that ‘[t]he stock of external arrears is estimated to be at 11 percent of GDP by end-2021, including arrears of USD 61 million to China.’ Then, in May 2023, the IMF announced the ‘[a]n agreement was reached with Paris Club (PC) creditors for a two-step debt treatment in June 2022, and bilateral agreements with most of the PC creditors have been completed. An agreement-in-principle with bondholders was reached on May 4, 2023. The authorities are actively negotiating in good faith with China and India on a debt restructuring agreement.’
staff_comments: 1. The China-Latin America Commercial Loans Tracker, which is produced by the Inter-American Dialogue, does not capture the ICBC loan that supported this project.2. The commercial contract between SPSB, Dalian International & Technical Cooperation Group Co Ltd. and the Housing Construction Fund for Lower Income Groups (Fonds Woningbouw Lager Inkomensgroepen) is also known as the “Construction of Houses and Supporting Infrastructure Phase II in Suriname” contract and the “Dalian Housing Phase II Contract.”3. ICBC made the issuance of a sovereign guarantee a condition of the loan agreement.4. This project is also known as the Dalian Housing Project Phase II or Construction of 700 Sets of Houses and Supporting Infrastructure (Dalian Phase II) Project. The Chinese project title is 第二阶段住房建设项目 or 本次大连二期项目. The Dutch project title is Dalian-woningbouwproject (fase twee) or Dalian woningbouwproject Fase II.4. On July 27, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of Suriname also signed an RMB 300,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 1 of the Low-Income Housing Project (as captured via Project ID#36772).5. It appears that the China Eximbank loan (captured by Project ID#36772) for Phase 1 of the Low-Income Housing Project and the ICBC loan for Phase 2 of the Low-Income Housing Project may have been jointly used to finance the $70 million USD commercial contract between Surinamese Postal Savings Bank (Surinaamse Postspaarbank or SPSB), Dalian International & Technical Cooperation Group Co Ltd. (CDIG) and the Housing Construction Fund for Lower Income Groups (Fonds Woningbouw Lager Inkomensgroepen). However, this issue requires further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
ICBC provides $30 million loan for Phase 2 of Low-Income Housing Project (Linked to Project ID#36772)

# Description
On March 27, 2018, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and the Surinamese Postal Savings Bank (Surinaamse Postspaarbank or SPSB) — a state-owned bank in Suriname — signed a $30 million loan agreement for Phase 2 of the Low-Income Housing Project. The loan carries a 3-year (36-month) maturity. The other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance a $70 million commercial contract between SPSB, Dalian International & Technical Cooperation Group Co Ltd. (CDIG) and the Housing Construction Fund for Lower Income Groups (Fonds Woningbouw Lager Inkomensgroepen). The Government of Suriname issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the ICBC loan to SPSB on March 27, 2018.   The purpose of this project is to construct 700 low-income housing units in the locality of Morgenstond (Dutch: Morgenstaat).   CDIG is the contractor responsible for implementation. The project officially commenced on or around March 16, 2018. It has reportedly employed 100 Chinese workers and 300 Surinamese workers. However, as of March 2022, AidData had not identified any evidence of project completion.   There are some indications that the ICBC loan issued for Phase 2 of Low-Income Housing Project may have underperformed vis-a-vis lender expectations. The Government of Suriname defaulted on its sovereign debt obligations three times during the COVID-19 pandemic. In December 2021, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) announced that ‘Suriname owes arrears to China and India, which have provided assurances, although less specific than those provided by the Paris Club creditors, that they intend to work with Suriname towards a debt restructuring that will restore sustainability. China has consented to [IMF] financing notwithstanding these arrears. [...] An update will be circulated to the [IMF] Executive Board not later than one week prior to the scheduled Board consideration. On the basis of the Surinamese authorities’ commitment noted above, staff expect that debt to China and India will be treated on comparable terms with other bilateral creditors. The arrears constitute a form of financing contribution to the program. China and India have acknowledged that Suriname will continue to run arrears on their official debt until a debt treatment can be agreed.’ The IMF also disclosed in December 2021 that ‘[t]he stock of external arrears is estimated to be at 11 percent of GDP by end-2021, including arrears of USD 61 million to China.’ Then, in May 2023, the IMF announced the ‘[a]n agreement was reached with Paris Club (PC) creditors for a two-step debt treatment in June 2022, and bilateral agreements with most of the PC creditors have been completed. An agreement-in-principle with bondholders was reached on May 4, 2023. The authorities are actively negotiating in good faith with China and India on a debt restructuring agreement.’
justification: Project focuses on low-income housing construction, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Construction of 700 low-income housing units, social infrastructure focus

title: China Donates Computers and Cameras to the Al-Watan Newspaper in Syria
description: On July 4, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Syria handed over a donation of computers and cameras to the "Al-Watan" newspaper in Damascus, Syria. This project is complete.
combined_text:

justification: Project involves donation of equipment to a media organization without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computers and cameras to newspaper, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government donates 5,404 tons of rice in 2018
description: In 2017, the Chinese Government agreed to donate a total of 5,504 tons of rice to Syria. The estimated monetary value of the donation is $2,196,481.28. The rice was to be delivered in batches of 1,000 to 1,200 tons. The first batch of 1,000 tons of rice was delivered to the city of Latakia on November 20, 2017. The last batch of rice was delivered on February 27, 2018. The food came as a form of aid in response to poor conditions in the country due to the ongoing war.
staff_comments: 1. To estimate the monetary value of the rice donation ($2,196,481.28), AidData takes the international price of a ton of rice in 2017 ($399.07) and multiplies it by 5,504 tons.2. The Arabic project title is 5504 أطنان من مادة الأرز.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates 5,404 tons of rice in 2018

# Description
In 2017, the Chinese Government agreed to donate a total of 5,504 tons of rice to Syria. The estimated monetary value of the donation is $2,196,481.28. The rice was to be delivered in batches of 1,000 to 1,200 tons. The first batch of 1,000 tons of rice was delivered to the city of Latakia on November 20, 2017. The last batch of rice was delivered on February 27, 2018. The food came as a form of aid in response to poor conditions in the country due to the ongoing war.
justification: Project is a humanitarian food donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Rice donation for emergency response, humanitarian aid focus

title: Chinese Government donates emergency power equipment worth $12 million in 2018
description: In 2018, the Chinese Government agreed to donate emergency power equipment to the Syrian Government worth $12 million. The donated equipment included 800 electrical power transformers with various capacities and 60 kilometer long electric cables. These power transformers of various capacities, distribution transformers, and cables arrived in 118 ocean containers at the Port of Latakia on October 10, 2018.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government donates emergency power equipment worth $12 million in 2018

# Description
In 2018, the Chinese Government agreed to donate emergency power equipment to the Syrian Government worth $12 million. The donated equipment included 800 electrical power transformers with various capacities and 60 kilometer long electric cables. These power transformers of various capacities, distribution transformers, and cables arrived in 118 ocean containers at the Port of Latakia on October 10, 2018.
justification: Project involves donation of electrical equipment for emergency power needs without clear energy transition implications
evidence: Emergency power equipment donation, transformers and cables for general electrical infrastructure

title: China finances surgeries for students with disabilities in Syria (linked to project ID#88535)
description: In July 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Syria covered the costs of surgeries and rehabilitation for two students with disabilities at the Amal school in Syria. In addition, the Embassy covered the cost of education for 100 students at the school for one year (#88535). This project is complete.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title

# Description
In July 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Syria covered the costs of surgeries and rehabilitation for two students with disabilities at the Amal school in Syria. In addition, the Embassy covered the cost of education for 100 students at the school for one year (#88535). This project is complete.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare and education support without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Surgeries and rehabilitation for students with disabilities, education funding for 100 students

title: Chinese Government donates medical equipment to Assad University Hospital
description: On March 8, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Syria donated 100 wheelchairs, 100 walkers, and 200 crutches to Assad University Hospital (مستشفى الاسد الجامعي.) in the city of Damascus. Al Assad University Hospital in Damascus is one of the largest teaching hospitals in Syria. It was founded in 1988 and is run by the Ministry of Higher Education. The hospital is affiliated with Damascus University.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical equipment to Assad University Hospital

# Description
On March 8, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Syria donated 100 wheelchairs, 100 walkers, and 200 crutches to Assad University Hospital (مستشفى الاسد الجامعي.) in the city of Damascus. Al Assad University Hospital in Damascus is one of the largest teaching hospitals in Syria. It was founded in 1988 and is run by the Ministry of Higher Education. The hospital is affiliated with Damascus University.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment to a hospital, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 100 wheelchairs, 100 walkers, and 200 crutches to Assad University Hospital

title: Chinese Embassy finances the education for AAMAL students for a year in Syria (linked to project ID#65283)
description: On July 8, 2018, China granted education expenses for 100 children with disabilities to cover one year to AAMAL, the Syrian Organization for the Disabled. This project was completed in July 2018, and exact origin of the funding is unknown. The Chinese Embassy made the donation to support the humanitarian cause of AAMAL.    Additionally, the Chinese Embassy covered the cost for the surgery of two Syrian Children with hearing issues (#65283).
combined_text:
# Sector

This project was completed in July 2018, and exact origin of the funding is unknown. The Chinese Embassy made the donation to support the humanitarian cause of AAMAL.    Additionally, the Chinese Embassy covered the cost for the surgery of two Syrian Children with hearing issues (#65283).
justification: Project focuses on education and healthcare support without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Education expenses for disabled children, healthcare support for hearing issues, humanitarian focus
